playerItems.h1: Attorney General Supports Electoral Bonds Scheme in Supreme Court

playerItems.p: Venkataramani backs the scheme, emphasizing its promotion of clean money in politics.
The scheme ensures tax obligations are met, according to the Attorney General.
Citizens' right to know is subject to reasonable restrictions under Article 19(2).
Constitution Bench to hear petitions on anonymous fund flow in electoral bonds.
Attorney General argues that the right to know should serve specific ends, not be overly broad.
The electoral bonds scheme is seen as a regulatory step under Article 19(2).

playerItems.h1: Supreme Court Dismisses Manish Sisodia's Bail Plea in Money Laundering Case

playerItems.p: Transfer of â‚¹338 crore established as a reason for denying bail.
Prosecution assures trial conclusion in six to eight months.
Sisodia can apply for bail if the trial proceeds sloppily.
Court questions PMLA charge without bribery charge against Sisodia.
Court emphasizes the need to establish a chain linking Sisodia with the liquor lobby.

playerItems.h1: PMLA Provisions and Proceeds of a Crime
playerItems.p: Discussion on when PMLA provisions apply, related to bribery and proceeds of a crime.
Sisodia's arrest and allegations of corruption in the Delhi Excise Policy.

playerItems.h1: Chief Justice Questions Indefinite Suspension of Raghav Chadha
Loss of Sense of Humor in Public Life
playerItems.p: Chief Justice Chandrachud comments on the death of humor in public life.
Chadha suspended for a casual quip and sending 'birthday invitation cards' to members.
Chief Justice questions if Chadha's remark reduced the House's dignity.
Importance of not excluding voices from the Parliament, even if they differ from the government.
Court expresses concern over indefinite suspension and the need for diverse voices in Parliament.
Chadha's argument against indefinite suspension and the potential for abuse of power.
